title: 114_hr3442
content: The Act titled "Debt Management and Fiscal Responsibility Act of 2015" requires the Secretary of the Treasury to report to Congress before reaching the debt limit. The "Debt Management and Fiscal Responsibility Act of 2015" mandates the Secretary of the Treasury to report to Congress 60-21 days before the public debt reaches the specified limit. The report must include historical debt levels. The "Debt Management and Fiscal Responsibility Act of 2015" requires the Secretary of the Treasury to provide a report to Congress on the state of the public debt, including historical levels, current amount, future projections, revenue levels, drivers of future debt, and measures to fund government obligations if the debt limit is not raised. The "Debt Management and Fiscal Responsibility Act of 2015" mandates the Secretary of the Treasury to inform Congress when the debt limit is reached and when measures are taken to fund government obligations if the limit is not raised. It also includes a provision for the President to recommend a balanced budget amendment to control future debt accumulation. Additionally, the Act requires a detailed explanation of the President's proposals to reduce the public debt in the short term. The "Debt Management and Fiscal Responsibility Act of 2015" requires the President to explain proposals to reduce public debt in the short, medium, and long term, adjust the debt-to-GDP ratio, assess the impact of increased debt on government spending and the dollar's status, and project the fiscal health of major entitlement programs like Social Security and Medicare. The "Debt Management and Fiscal Responsibility Act of 2015" mandates the President to disclose reduction measures used to avoid default on government obligations when the U.S. debt reaches its limit. This includes details on the total dollar amount of each measure being utilized. The "Debt Management and Fiscal Responsibility Act of 2015" requires the President to disclose the total dollar amount of reduction measures being used to avoid default when the U.S. debt limit is reached. This includes information on available funds, the estimated exhaustion date of measures, and any extraordinary measures planned to fund government obligations if the debt limit is not raised. The "Debt Management and Fiscal Responsibility Act of 2015" mandates the President to reveal the reduction measures used to prevent default when the debt limit is reached. This includes details on available funds, the projected exhaustion date of measures, and any extraordinary measures planned to fund government obligations if the debt limit is not raised. Additionally, a progress report on implementing the President's proposals must be submitted. The Secretary of the Treasury must provide a link on the Department of the Treasury's homepage to a webpage containing public access information for at least 6 months. This includes the debt report, detailed explanation, progress report, and any other necessary information for public understanding. The Secretary of the Treasury must provide public access information on the Department of the Treasury's website for at least 6 months, including debt reports, explanations, and progress reports. Reduction measures defined in this section include directing debt issuance, suspending investments in various funds. The Secretary of the Treasury can take measures such as suspending new investments in retirement funds, selling assets before maturity, and other appropriate actions as deemed necessary. A clerical amendment is made to the table of analysis for chapter 31 of title 31, United States Code. The House of Representatives passed a report on reaching the debt limit on February 11, 2016, attested by Karen L. Haas, Clerk.
